text:
-I remember walking my dogs
about a week after 9/11.

And there was a bumper sticker
on a car in my neighborhood,

and it said, we're praying for
the families of September 11.

I remember thinking, my gosh,
they're talking about me.

-He was 28 years old, and he
worked for an outfit called
Euro Brokers.

What I was told was that he had
stayed behind, and he was

helping this heavy-set lady
down the stairs, and some

older fellow who was having a
difficult time I guess with
the conditions in there.

-Losing a child is the hardest
thing that you can ever do.

A child is just so much
a part of you.
You gave birth to it.

You raised, you put a lot of
time and effort into making

him a good, contributing
individual who just gave back.
And then he's gone.

He walks out your door Sunday
night, and he's gone Tuesday

morning because he
went to work.

It was just very hard
for me to grasp.

But I thought if I could stop
time, just for a few seconds,
I could change everything.

And I really had to fight that
for maybe two years.

-To try and characterize the
last 10 years, it's hard to

really do in a word
or two or three.

The best I can say is,
it's a journey.

I was healthy as a horse prior
to 9/11, and now I have a

number of different things
that I deal with.

Leukemia, MS, and I'm basically
blind, or about 97%.
So was it a stress--

was this all brought
on by stress?

My guess is probably,
more than likely.

-A lot of what he used to do now
shifts to me, and I'm very
tired of reading manuals.

But with Brett's death and
having to deal with that, I

think once you can deal with
that, or cope with it, I think
you can cope with anything.

The majority of the money from
Brett's foundation helps the

families of the New
Jersey National
Guards who are serving.

We said, since he was killed
by terrorists, we wanted to

help the families of those
who were protecting us.

-Why Brett has such lasting
friends, and why the bonds, I

think, were so strong, is
because one of his strongest

qualities was his faithfulness
and his loyalty to friendship.

-She was a special part of our
life, and then she ended up
marrying his best friend.
It was a blessing.

It was hard going to the
wedding, but I'm happy that

they just had their
third child.

-His life, I think, was like--
you take a pebble, throw it in

the water, and you
see the ripples.
And that's carried forward.

So I know I take a lot of solace
in remembering those
qualities about him.
